prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J0109 - H2O + CO(10-9)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Setup to observe H2O and CO(10-9) in J0109 at z=6.791

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitvity: We request a sensitivity of 0.15 mJy per 300 km/s channel to detect the H2O and CO(10-9) lines in all of our targets as outlined in the main proposal.
Imaging: This is a pure detection experiment of sources that are unresolved on scales of a few arcseconds. Therefore we request observations in one of the compact configurations (C34-1 or C34-2).
Correlator setup: We have put one spw each on the H2O and CO(10-9) lines. The other two spws in the other sidebands will be used to obtain an accurate measurement of the continuum. We request spectral averaging of ‘8’, which will still lead to high spectral resolution (~10 km/s) and thus open up the possibility of serendipitous line detections.
Calibration: Default calibration is requested
Bandpass accuracy: No special accuracy requested
Data rate: Our data rate is below the expected average rate of 6 MB/s

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J0109 - OH
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Setup to observe OH in J0109 at z=6.791

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitvity: We request a sensitivity of 0.2 mJy per 300 km/s channel to detect the OH line in all of our targets as outlined in the main proposal and the Table 1.
Imaging: This is a pure detection experiment of sources that are unresolved on scales of a few arcseconds. Therefore we request observations in one of the compact configurations (C34-1 or C34-2).
Correlator setup: We have centered the OH line in one spw. The other three spws are used to obtain an accurate measurement of the continuum. We request spectral averaging of ‘8’ which will still lead to high spectral resolution (~10 km/s) and thus open up the possibility of serendipitous line detections.
Calibration: Default calibration is requested
Bandpass accuracy: No special accuracy requested
Data rate: Our data rate is below the expected average rate of 6 MB/s

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J2348 - OH
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Setup to observe OH in J2348 at z=6.904

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The highest redshift quasars provide an absolutely unique opportunity to study massive galaxy formation when the universe was in its infancy (the 'epoch of reionization'). We have recently detected [CII] emission and the underlying continuum in the 4 highest redshift quasars known to date (6.6<z<7.1, age of the universe: ~800 Myr). These measurements demonstrate that even these highest redshift quasar hosts are actively forming stars, consistent with studies at lower redshifts. The high redshift of the sources, in addition to newly available ALMA bands, now allow us to obtain key measurements of the interstellar medium that were inconceivable just a few years ago: the detection of H2O, a tracer of dense gas, and OH, a tracer of molecular outflows. At the same time, our observations will cover the CO(10-9) line and the underlying continuum. Based on our recent groundwork on the z=6.42 quasar J1148+5251 using PdBI, all lines will be detected with ALMA with our observational setup. The proposed observations of a sample of quasar hosts at the highest accessible redshift will shed new light on massive galaxy formation (including the role of feedback) in the early universe.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Domenici Science Operations Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
